channel.title: Health Care : NPR
channel.description: The state of health care, health insurance, new medical research, disease prevention, and drug treatments. Interviews, news, and commentary from NPR's correspondents. Subscribe to podcasts.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Cleveland Pressures Hospitals To Keep ERs Open To All Ambulances
item.description: When you call an ambulance, you expect to go to the nearest hospital. But patients are often diverted to more distant emergency rooms. Cleveland wants hospitals to stop the practice.
item.content:encoded: When you call an ambulance, you expect to go to the nearest hospital. But patients are often diverted to more distant emergency rooms. Cleveland wants hospitals to stop the practice.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Jane Tribble

item.title: N.J. Factory Turns To Medicaid To Insure Lowest-Paid Employees
item.description: Starting Jan. 1, midsize companies must offer health insurance to their workers or risk a penalty. A firm that has already faced that problem is helping low-paid employees enroll in Medicaid, instead.
item.content:encoded: Starting Jan. 1, midsize companies must offer health insurance to their workers or risk a penalty. A firm that has already faced that problem is helping low-paid employees enroll in Medicaid, instead.
item.dc:creator: Fred Mogul

item.title: Obamacare Insurers Sweeten Plans With Free Doctor Visits
item.description: Some insurers are betting that lowering the barrier to seeing a doctor will encourage people to get needed care sooner. If it works, the health plans could save more than they spend on the benefit.
item.content:encoded: Some insurers are betting that lowering the barrier to seeing a doctor will encourage people to get needed care sooner. If it works, the health plans could save more than they spend on the benefit.
item.dc:creator: Phil Galewitz

item.title: Doctors Look To Prevent Abuse In Midst Of Opioid Epidemic
item.description: The U.S. is in the grips of a prescription drug epidemic, fueled in part by an explosion in opioid prescriptions over the past several decades. Roughly half of those prescriptions are written by primary care doctors. NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Dr. Wanda Filer, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, about her experience prescribing opioids and what doctors can do to prevent abuse.
item.content:encoded: The U.S. is in the grips of a prescription drug epidemic, fueled in part by an explosion in opioid prescriptions over the past several decades. Roughly half of those prescriptions are written by primary care doctors. NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Dr. Wanda Filer, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, about her experience prescribing opioids and what doctors can do to prevent abuse.

item.title: 2015 Was Another Rough And Tumble Year For Obamacare
item.description: The Affordable Care Act survived another challenge before the U.S. Supreme Court this year. But the still-fragile marketplace is showing the strain of rising health care costs.
item.content:encoded: The Affordable Care Act survived another challenge before the U.S. Supreme Court this year. But the still-fragile marketplace is showing the strain of rising health care costs.
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Privacy Violations Rising At Veterans Affairs Medical Facilities
item.description: Deceased veterans' documents were sent to the wrong widows. VA workers snooped on patients who had committed suicide. And whistleblowers contend the VA violated their medical privacy.
item.content:encoded: Deceased veterans' documents were sent to the wrong widows. VA workers snooped on patients who had committed suicide. And whistleblowers contend the VA violated their medical privacy.
item.dc:creator: Annie Waldman

item.title: A Cause For Cautious Celebration: Guinea Is Ebola-Free
item.description: After two years and over 2,500 deaths, the country's epidemic has officially ended, the World Health Organization says. Health groups will be watching to ensure the virus doesn't re-emerge.
item.content:encoded: After two years and over 2,500 deaths, the country's epidemic has officially ended, the World Health Organization says. Health groups will be watching to ensure the virus doesn't re-emerge.
item.dc:creator: Maanvi Singh

item.title: New VA Clinic Opens For Transgender Vets
item.description: The Tucson Veterans Affairs hospital is expanding treatment to the needs of trans veterans, one of the first such facilities in the U.S. to do so. The clinic's services include hormone treatment.
item.content:encoded: The Tucson Veterans Affairs hospital is expanding treatment to the needs of trans veterans, one of the first such facilities in the U.S. to do so. The clinic's services include hormone treatment.
item.dc:creator: Jimmy Jenkins

item.title: How Sound Reveals The Invisible Within Us
item.description: Microscopes illuminate the tiny. But sound? Scientists didn't really see it as all that important, until an amazing invention came along that opened new worlds: the stethoscope.
item.content:encoded: Microscopes illuminate the tiny. But sound? Scientists didn't really see it as all that important, until an amazing invention came along that opened new worlds: the stethoscope.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Joyce

item.title: Repeat Violators Of Health Privacy Laws Often Go Unpunished
item.description: Regulators have logged dozens, even hundreds of complaints against some health providers for violating federal patient privacy law. Warnings are doled out privately, and sanctions are rarely imposed.
item.content:encoded: Regulators have logged dozens, even hundreds of complaints against some health providers for violating federal patient privacy law. Warnings are doled out privately, and sanctions are rarely imposed.
item.dc:creator: Charles Ornstein

item.title: Gene Editing Tool Hailed As A Breakthrough, And It Really Is One
item.description: A tool for modifying genes is spreading through the biomedical research world like wildfire. As part of the series Joe's Big Idea, NPR's Joe Palca explores why CRISPR-Cas9 is becoming indispensable.
item.content:encoded: A tool for modifying genes is spreading through the biomedical research world like wildfire. As part of the series Joe's Big Idea, NPR's Joe Palca explores why CRISPR-Cas9 is becoming indispensable.
item.dc:creator: Joe Palca

item.title: Alzheimer's Disease Underdiagnosed In Indian Country
item.description: A Native American family that sees Alzheimer's disease as a natural part of life may be less likely to reach for resources that could help, say Arizona mental health workers. They hope to change that.
item.content:encoded: A Native American family that sees Alzheimer's disease as a natural part of life may be less likely to reach for resources that could help, say Arizona mental health workers. They hope to change that.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Morales

item.title: Training The Immune System To Fight Cancer Has 19th-Century Roots
item.description: When Jimmy Carter said his advanced melanoma was gone, he credited immunotherapy, treatments that harness the immune system to fight cancer cells. This idea dates back to a 19th-century doctor.
item.content:encoded: When Jimmy Carter said his advanced melanoma was gone, he credited immunotherapy, treatments that harness the immune system to fight cancer cells. This idea dates back to a 19th-century doctor.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis

item.title: States Deny Pricey Hepatitis C Drugs To Most Medicaid Patients
item.description: Effective treatments for hepatitis C cost as much as $95,000. Medicaid in many states, including Indiana, is mostly limiting the drugs' use to very advanced cases. ACLU of Indiana is suing the state.
item.content:encoded: Effective treatments for hepatitis C cost as much as $95,000. Medicaid in many states, including Indiana, is mostly limiting the drugs' use to very advanced cases. ACLU of Indiana is suing the state.
item.dc:creator: Jake Harper

item.title: ER Docs Say Rule Change Could Raise Patients' Out-Of-Network Bills
item.description: Two physicians groups say federal government regulations for out-of-network emergency care payments will cost consumers more because insurers will pay less.
item.content:encoded: Two physicians groups say federal government regulations for out-of-network emergency care payments will cost consumers more because insurers will pay less.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Andrews
